content: The Act may be cited as the "Lena Horne Recognition Act". Lena Horne, born in 1917 in Brooklyn, New York, started her career as a dancer at the Cotton Club. She later became the first African-American woman to perform with an all-White band and signed a long-term contract with MGM. Despite her talent, she faced limitations in acting roles due to her race. Lena Horne faced acting limitations due to her race, with scenes of her singing often cut in the South. Despite this, she impressed in films like "Cabin in the Sky" and "Stormy Weather" before focusing on a successful career in show business. She also supported American troops during World War II by touring with the USO. Lena Horne actively protested segregation and discrimination in the military, refusing to perform for segregated audiences and speaking out on the issue. She was blacklisted as a communist during McCarthyism for her civil rights activism. In 1957, she recorded Lena Horne at the USO on the West Coast and in the South. Lena Horne rose to international stardom, touring with famous musicians and starring in specials with icons like Judy Garland and Frank Sinatra. She used her fame to advocate for civil rights, participating in the historic March on Washington in 1963. Lena Horne gained respect for her courage in the Civil Rights movement, meeting President John F. Kennedy before his death. She performed at rallies for various organizations and appeared on popular American TV shows. Throughout the 20th century, she continued to entertain diverse audiences. Lena Horne, an entertainer, activist, and mother, captivated audiences with her one-woman Broadway show "Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music" in 1981, earning special Tony and Grammy Awards. She was the first woman nominated for a Tony Award in the 1950s. Halle Berry, in 2002, became the first African-American woman to win an Oscar for Best Actress, acknowledging Lena Horne's trailblazing legacy. Lena Horne passed away in New York City on May 9, 2010, at the age of 92. Lena Horne, an entertainer, activist, and mother, used her beauty, talent, and intelligence to fight racial discrimination and rise to international stardom. She entertained people from all walks of life for over 60 years, breaking barriers for future generations. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for the posthumous presentation of a gold medal to honor Lena Horne for her achievements in American culture and the civil rights movement. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Additionally, duplicate medals will be made. The Secretary is authorized to produce and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal created under this Act. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under specific sections of the United States Code.
